title: Arabs in Berlin
text:
Arabs in Berlin form the fourth-largest ethnic minority group in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, after the <a href="Turkish%20people">Turkish</a>, <a href="Poles">Polish</a> and <a href="Russians">Russian</a> community. As of December 2017, there are about 135,000 people of any <a href="Arab">Arab</a> origin residing in the city, which corresponds to 3.5% of the population.
History.
Most Arabs came to <a href="Germany">Germany</a> in the 1970s, partly as <a href="Gastarbeiter">Gastarbeiter</a> from <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>, the Turkish Province of <a href="Mardin%20Province">Mardin</a> (see: <a href="Arabs%20in%20Turkey">Arabs in Turkey</a>) and <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>. However, the majority of Arabs in Berlin are <a href="refugees">refugees</a> of the conflicts in the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a>, e.g. the <a href="1982%20Lebanon%20War">Lebanon Wars</a>, <a href="Palestinian%20exodus%20from%20Kuwait%20%28Gulf%20War%29">Palestinian exodus</a>, the recent <a href="Iraq%20War">Iraq War</a>, <a href="Libyan%20Civil%20War%20%282011%29">Libyan Civil War</a> and <a href="Syrian%20Civil%20War">Syrian Civil War</a>. The Arabs in Berlin are not a homogeneous group because they originate from about 20 countries.
Distribution.
Similar to the <a href="Turks%20in%20Berlin">Turkish community</a>, Arab people are primarily concentrated in the inner-city boroughs of former <a href="West%20Berlin">West Berlin</a>.
In the case of <a href="Neuk%C3%B6lln">Neukölln</a>, 80% of Arabs live in the same-named locality of <a href="Neuk%C3%B6lln%20%28locality%29">Neukölln</a>, forming up to 10% of the populace. Around 35,000 are of <a href="State%20of%20Palestine">Palestinian</a> and 15,000 of <a href="Lebanon">Lebanese</a> origin. The rest of 20,000 are mostly of <a href="Morocco">Moroccan</a>, <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>i, <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>n, <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>ian, <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>n, <a href="Libya">Libya</a>n and <a href="Syria">Syria</a>n origin.
